newsitem.title: CANADA: HORSE RACING-STORM SONG CHARGES TO VICTORY AT BREEDERS' CUP.
newsitem.headline: HORSE RACING-STORM SONG CHARGES TO VICTORY AT BREEDERS' CUP.

text.p: Storm Song came from mid-pack at the quarter pole to chase down and roar past Love That Jazz and win the 1-1/16-mile Juvenile Fillies, the opening race of the Breeders' Cup on Saturday.
Storm Song, an 8-5 favourite in the race for two year olds, had plenty of run left at the finish line, winning by four lengths going away.
Critical Factor was third and Minister's Melody was fourth.
Storm Song, bought for $100,000 earlier this year, won $520,000. Second place was worth $200,000 and third $120,000.
"This is a terrific filly. She put her last two races behind her and got it all together," said winning jockey Craig Perret, referring to Storm Song losing her last two races. "She's the queen."

Love That Jazz broke quickly to take the lead going into the first turn and opened up a two-length lead by the 1/4 mile pole and lengthened that margin to three lengths at half a mile. Love That Jazz was attempting to become the first to win the Breeders' Cup juvenile filly wire to wire.
But Storm Song, fifth at the 3/4 pole, made her move at the top of the stretch and breezed past Love That Jazz for her fourth win in seven outings this year.
It was the first Breeders' Cup victory for veteran trainer Nick Zito.

Critical Factor's trainer Myung Kwon Cho said of his horse: "She almost fell down at the gate. I never though we'd have any problem there because she has enough speed. But we're very proud of the way she finished."
Celebrated trainer D. Wayne Lukas, had three horses in the race but was shut out.
